results.abstract: Sen John Kerry rebukes Pres Bush for remarks that he had made 'miscalculation' in Iraq and that he doubts fight against terrorism is winnable; says with right policies, it is war that must be won and calls miscalculation more profound than underestimating how quickly country could be pacified; says Bush ignored advice of military advisers; makes it clear that he faults civilian leadership, not military; says he would have conducted operation differently and cites examples; photo (M)

headline.kicker: THE REPUBLICANS: THE CONVENTION IN NEW YORK -- THE DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE
headline.main: Kerry Tells Veterans Bush Fails on Iraq and Terror

results.snippet: Senator John Kerry rebuked President Bush on Wednesday for his handling of both issues, saying that "extremism has gained momentum."
results.lead_paragraph: Seizing on President Bush's remarks in the last week that he had made a ''miscalculation'' in Iraq and that he doubted that the fight against terrorism was winnable, Senator John Kerry rebuked him on Wednesday for his handling of both, saying that ''extremism has gained momentum.'' ''I absolutely disagree with what he said in that interview in a moment of candor,'' Mr. Kerry said here at the American Legion's national convention a day after Mr. Bush, before the same audience, retreated from a televised comment in which he said he did not think the United States could win the war on terror.

results.abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews Echo Night: Beyond, Ghosthunter and The Political Machine; photos (M)

headline.main: The Eerie Allure of Ghosts and the Electoral College

results.snippet: In Echo Night: Beyond, an adventure game, all ghosts really want is for someone to bring them stuff.
results.lead_paragraph: ECHO NIGHT: BEYOND Developed by From Software and published by Agetec for PlayStation 2; $39.99; for ages 13 and older. GHOSTHUNTER Developed by Sony Company Entertainment Europe Studio Cambridge and published by Namco for PlayStation 2; $49.99; for ages 13 and older. THE POLITICAL MACHINE Developed by Stardock and published by UbiSoft for Windows 98 and later; $19.99; ages 13 and older.

results.abstract: Sen John Kerry steps up effort to put Pres Bush on defensive over Iraq, saying conditions are so bad that January elections are in jeopardy, and Bush's claims of improvement do not match reality; brief address in Columbus, just after Prime Min Ayad Allawi addresses Congress, charges Bush misleads Americans and stubbornly refuses to change course; cites CIA estimates, reporting and ground operations that all tell different story about mounting violence; says he would do better job of training Iraqis to provide security and rallying other nations to help; adds that Bush 'skedaddled' out of New York without talking to world leaders at UN; Vice Pres Cheney suggests Kerry is defeatist; photos of Kerry in Philadelphia with boxing champion Bernard Hopkins, and Bush in Bangor (M)

headline.main: Kerry Accuses President Of Misleading U.S. on Iraq

results.snippet: Senator John Kerry said that conditions in Iraq were so bad that the elections planned for January were in jeopardy.

byline.original: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON; David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Bangor, Me., for this article

results.lead_paragraph: Stepping up his efforts to put President Bush on the defensive over Iraq, Senator John Kerry said on Thursday that conditions there were so bad there that the elections planned for January were in jeopardy and that the president's assertions that things were improving did not match reality. Speaking just after Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq said at a joint session of Congress that the elections would go ahead on schedule, and just before Mr. Bush told a news conference that Iraq had made ''steady progress,'' Mr. Kerry suggested that the president was misleading the American people and stubbornly unwilling to change course.

results.abstract: NASA officials say new crew will be sent to International Space Station on October 11 aboard Russian Soyuz spacecraft despite concerns about oxygen and supplies on space station; Dr Leroy Chiao and Salizhan S Sharipov will relieve Col Gennadi I Padalka and Lt Col Edward Mike Fincke; supplies will be replenished by deliveries in late December and February; balky oxygen generator is problem, but station has 160-day oxygen supply from other sources should it fail (M)

headline.main: New Crew to Leave for Space Station on Oct. 11, NASA Says

results.snippet: A new crew will be sent to the International Space Station next month, even though there are concerns about adequate oxygen and other supplies.
results.lead_paragraph: A new crew will be sent to the International Space Station next month, even though there are concerns about maintaining adequate oxygen and other supplies on the orbiting laboratory, NASA officials said Friday. The space station program manager, William H. Gerstenmaier, said two astronauts would be launched to the station on a Russian Soyuz spacecraft on Oct. 11 for an expected six-month tour of duty.

results.abstract: Lower Broadway is paved with 164 granite plaques from Bowling Green to Woolworth Building to commemorate ticker-tape parades from October 1886, when Statue of Liberty was dedicated, to October 2000, when Yankees last won World Series; they were commissioned before 9/11 under plan by Alliance for Downtown New York to improve streetscape with new sidewalks, lampposts, signs and wastebaskets; photo (M)

headline.main: Heady Days, Immortalized Where the Ticker Tape Fell

results.snippet: Lower Broadway has been paved with 164 granite plaques commemorating the city's ticker-tape parades.
results.lead_paragraph: IN the midst of the longest ticker-tape drought in a quarter century, lower Broadway -- the Canyon of Heroes -- has been paved instead with 164 granite plaques from Bowling Green to the Woolworth Building. They commemorate ticker-tape parades from October 1886, when the Statue of Liberty was dedicated, to October 2000, when the Yankees last won the World Series. They were commissioned before 9/11 under a plan by the Alliance for Downtown New York to improve the streetscape with new sidewalks, lampposts, signs and wastebaskets.
